title: About Me
text:
I am passionate about leveraging data to uncover insights and drive data-informed business decisions. I enjoy applying statistical methods and machine learning techniques to real-world problems, including areas such as sports analytics, mental health research, and predictive modeling. I also enjoy creating interactive dashboards and conducting exploratory analyses to reveal meaningful patterns.



Education:I hold a Master’s degree in Data Analytics from the University of Massachusetts Amherst, which has provided me with a strong foundation in statistical methods, data interpretation, and analytical problem-solving.



I have worked in the finance industry for the past six years and currently serve as a Data Analytics Senior Consultant. In this role, I focus on investigating datasets, uncovering actionable insights, and supporting broader organizational goals through data-driven strategies.



 Download My Resume
Thanks for checking out my web site!

title: Projects
text:
Boston Weather ETL Pipeline This project automates the collection and processing of Boston weather data. Historical data from NOAA and real-time data from the Open-Meteo API are ingested, stored in AWS S3, and processed via AWS Glue into structured formats. The pipeline runs daily, ensuring up-to-date datasets for analysis and visualization. Processed data powers a Streamlit dashboard for monitoring current weather conditions, and the system includes logging, scheduling, and alerting to ensure reliability. This ETL workflow provides a robust, automated solution for maintaining high-quality, ready-to-use weather data for research or operational use.
View the Boston Weather GitHub Repository

title: Projects
text:
Streamlit Dashboard:
Boston Weather Dashboard – Demonstration



The chart above shows the daily maximum (TMAX) and minimum (TMIN) temperatures in Boston for a given month. The lighter line represents the daily highs, while the darker line shows the daily lows. Peaks indicate warmer days, and valleys indicate cooler days. This visualization highlights temperature variability and trends over the month, providing a quick way to spot unusually hot or cold days.This shows November of 2025.
This chart is part of the interactive Boston Weather Dashboard, where users can filter by year and month, view precipitation, and see daily weather flags (“Above”, “Below”, “Average”) for deeper insights.
Open Live Boston Weather Dashboard
